Musk Muscles His Rivals Out In Space Race Concerns Rise as U.S. Relies on SpaceX

By ERIC LIPTON WASHINGTON - Elon Musk
aggressively elbowed his way into the space launch business over
the past two decades, combining engineering genius and an entre-
preneurial drive with a demand that the U.S. government stop favoring the big, slow-moving con-
tractors that had long dominated Today, it Today, it is Mr. Musk who is
dominant. His company, SpaceX, is the primary provider of launch
services to NASA and to the Penservices to NASA and to the Pen-
tagon. His rockets carry far more
commercial satellites into orbit than anyone else's, including
those for his own Starlink communications network. He has set new
standards for reaching space cheaply and reliably.
But in one striking way, the for-
mer outsider has come to resemble the entrenched contractors he
once fought to topple: He is increasingly using his vast powe
and influence to try to emerging rivals at bay, his com-
petitors say, even as his success is prompting qualms within the gov-
ernment about such heavy reliance on a mercurial billionaire. entrepreneurs trying to emulate

LAWYERS DELIVER CLOSING APPEALS TO TRUMP JURORS

FINAL CHANCE TO SWAY
Where the Defense Sees a Victim, Prosecutors

See a Schemer

This article is by Ben Protess, Jo-
nah E. Bromwich and Maggie Ha-
berman.
berman
For nearly three hours on Tues-
day, Donald J. Trump's lawyer did day, Donald J. Trump's lawyer did
his level best to persuade the jury
to acquit hat his acquit his client, wielding a scalpel to attack nearly every
strand of the criminal case against Strand of the criminal
the former president. Then it was a prosecutor's turn.
Rather than using a fine blade, he swung a sledgehammer. Throughout a marathon closing
argument that nearly outlasted
daylight the daylight, the prosecutor delivered
a sweeping rebuke of the former president, seeking to persuade
the jury of 12 New Yorkers that Mr Thump had falsified records to cover up a sex scandal involving a porn star. The prosecutor, Joshua
Steinglass, wove together witness Steinglass, wove together witness
testimony and documents to drive home the key points of the weeks long case, the first criminal trial of an American president.
Facing the judge's 8 p.
line, Mr. Steinglass raced to the
wire, stopping only the wire, stopping only to take a gulp
of water as the sky darkened outof water as the sky darkened out-
side the towering courtroom windows.
"Everything Mr. Trump and his cohorts did in this case was
cloaked in lies" Mr Steinglas cloaked in lies," Mr. Steinglass
said as the jurors, who had been glued to most of his presentation,
began to fidget in their seats. By the fidget in the prosecuts.

Trump arriving at court for closing arguments on Tuesday.
to other business and the traffic on Lower Manhattan streets had
slowed. More than 10 hours after Mr. Trump's lawyer began the day Mr. Trump's lawyer begant he day
by calling the case "absurd" and "preposterous," Mr. Steinglass fi-
nally had the final word nally had the final word.
The disparate strategie The disparate strategies - Mr
Steinglass's closing was more Steinglass's closing was more
than twice as long as the defense's - reflected their separate tasks. The defense needed only to estab-
lish reasonable doubt while the rosecution needed to persuade the jury to accept a narrative that, Mr. Steinglass argued, could lead
to only one ending: guilty on all counts.
